entry.title: Re: Connect SAP ByDesign to best-of-breed HCM Solutions
entry.content:
I‚Äôm currently working on automating the creation and maintenance of employee private addresses in SAP Business ByDesign using n8n and the ManageEmployeeIn web service (EmployeeDataBundleMaintainRequest_sync).

The request executes successfully, but the address is always created on the Business Partner record only ‚Äî it never appears under Personnel Administration ‚Üí Private Address in the employee master data.

Here‚Äôs a simplified example of the XML request:

<soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/">
  <soapenv:Header/>
  <soapenv:Body>
    <n0:EmployeeDataBundleMaintainRequest_sync xmlns:n0="http://sap.com/xi/SAPGlobal20/Global">
      <BasicMessageHeader/>
      <EmployeeData
        actionCode="04"
        addressInformationListCompleteTransmissionIndicator="true"
        workplaceAddressInformationListCompleteTransmissionIndicator="false"
        identificationListCompleteTransmissionIndicator="false"
        commonListCompleteTransmissionIndicator="false">

        <ObjectNodeSenderTechnicalID>Root</ObjectNodeSenderTechnicalID>
        <ChangeStateID>{{ChangeStateID}}</ChangeStateID>
        <UUID>{{EmployeeUUID}}</UUID>

        <AddressInformation actionCode="04">
          <ValidityPeriod>
            <StartDate>{{Today}}</StartDate>
            <EndDate>9999-12-31</EndDate>
          </ValidityPeriod>
          <Address actionCode="04">
            <PostalAddress actionCode="04">
              <CountryCode>DE</CountryCode>
              <CityName>{{City}}</CityName>
              <StreetName>{{Street}}</StreetName>
              <HouseID>{{HouseNo}}</HouseID>
              <StreetPostalCode>{{PostalCode}}</StreetPostalCode>
            </PostalAddress>
          </Address>
        </AddressInformation>

      </EmployeeData>
    </n0:EmployeeDataBundleMaintainRequest_sync>
  </soapenv:Body>
</soapenv:Envelope>

The service responds without errors, but the resulting address always has usage type XXDEFAULT and is only visible under the Business Partner data.

When creating the same address manually via Personnel Administration, the system automatically sets:

ProtectedIndicator = true

AddressUsageCode = HCM001 (Employee private address)

DefaultIndicator = true

However, these attributes don‚Äôt seem to be available in the ManageEmployeeIn WSDL ‚Äî neither under EmployeePrivateAddressInformation nor within PostalAddress.

My questions:

How can a private address (HCM001) be created correctly so that it appears under Personnel Administration ‚Üí Private Address?

Is this possible at all via ManageEmployeeIn, or should another interface (e.g. ManageBusinessPartnerIn or a dedicated HR service) be used instead?

Any insights or a working XML example would be greatly appreciated!

entry.title: Marketplace App UX Design Guidelines for SAP Users
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I'm currently exploring how to design and optimize Marketplace apps (or plug-ins) that integrate with SAP systems, and I'd love to gather insights from the community on user experience (UX) best practices specific to SAP users. I've noticed that while SAP provides extensive functionality, UX expectations can differ greatly from those of users in other enterprise platforms.

Many SAP users value clarity, consistency, and workflow efficiency over flashy design ‚Äî but I'm curious how others have balanced usability with SAP‚Äôs complex interfaces. Here are a few things I'd love to discuss:

1. What UX principles or design guidelines have you found most effective when building apps for SAP users?
2. How do you ensure visual and functional consistency with the SAP native interface?
3. Are there any common UX pitfalls (navigation issues, data overload, confusing layouts) to avoid when integrating with SAP?
4. Do you follow SAP Fiori design guidelines, or do you adapt them to fit Marketplace or third-party app environments?
5. Any examples of well-designed SAP-integrated Marketplace apps that you think set a strong standard?

I'm hoping this thread can serve as a space for designers, developers, and product teams to share design standards, frameworks, and real-world lessons that improve the SAP user experience.

Thanks in advance for your insights; your experiences could really help shape a more consistent and intuitive design approach for SAP users across Marketplace solutions.

entry.title: Re: Inspection for delivery saved with warnings; see logM...
entry.content:
Go to SU3 or SU01, and look for parameters like WERKS, QALS, QMAT, QINSP (quality-related). Compare with a working user, even one missing or misconfigured parameter can cause unexpected behavior.

In MSR_INSPWH, users can save personal variants or layouts. Ask the affected user to reset their layout (via Settings ‚Üí Layout ‚Üí Manage). Try running the transaction with no variant selected.

Go to SLG1, input Object as MSR_INSP, Subobject as INSPECTION. Enter the affected user ID and date range. This will show the exact warning message and context ‚Äî often pointing to missing data or failed logic.

entry.title: Re: Dynamic Multilevel approval Workflow using Block Step
entry.content:
Hi everyone, my requirement is a bit off topic but is of a workflow where I am stuck. Its an approval worflow on Sale order and is working fine. the only issue I am facing is that its not holding on the approvers (which i am fetching from a Z table). Its getting thrown in all approvers inbox but if any of the approvers approve, the WI is executed. I want it to check the approvers ( Max 3 levels are maintained in table) and until the last approvers doesnt approve, it should not get executed, whereas executed immediately when rejected on any level. In my user decision, I have a rule defined which has an FM running. Kindly guide me to resolve this. TIA

FM:
FUNCTION zfm_rule_so.
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*"  TABLES
*"      actor_tab STRUCTURE  swhaactor
*"      ac_container STRUCTURE  swcont
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------

  DATA: wa_actor     TYPE swhactor,
        wa_container TYPE swcont,
        lv_lines     TYPE i,
        lv_vbeln     TYPE vbak-vbeln,
        lv_vtweg     TYPE vbak-vtweg,
        lt_approvers TYPE TABLE OF zso_iq,
        wa_approver  TYPE zso_iq,
        lv_decision  TYPE char1,       " Decision from WF (A/R/P)
        lv_objnr     TYPE jest-objnr,  " Object number for status mgmt
        lv_sts       TYPE jsto-stsma.  " User status to be set

  "------------------------------------------------
  " 1. Read Sales Order number from WF container
  "------------------------------------------------
  READ TABLE ac_container INTO wa_container WITH KEY element = 'SO_N'.
  IF sy-subrc = 0 AND wa_container-value IS NOT INITIAL.
    lv_vbeln = wa_container-value.

    "------------------------------------------------
    " 2. Get approvers from custom Z-table
    "------------------------------------------------
    SELECT SINGLE vtweg
      INTO lv_vtweg
      FROM vbak
      WHERE vbeln = lv_vbeln.

    SELECT *
      INTO TABLE lt_approvers
      FROM zso_iq
      WHERE dist_ch = lv_vtweg
      ORDER BY level_app ASCENDING.

    LOOP AT lt_approvers INTO wa_approver.
      CLEAR wa_actor.
      wa_actor-otype = 'US'.
      wa_actor-objid = wa_approver-userid.
      APPEND wa_actor TO actor_tab.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDIF.

  " Remove duplicates
  DELETE ADJACENT DUPLICATES FROM actor_tab COMPARING objid.

  " Raise exception if no approvers found
  DESCRIBE TABLE actor_tab LINES lv_lines.
  IF lv_lines = 0.
    RAISE nobody_found.
  ENDIF.

entry.title: Enhancing SAP Business Events with Custom Payload Fields using RAP
entry.content:
Introduction

When working with SAP Event Mesh and business partner events, you might encounter scenarios where the default event payload contains only basic information, such as the Business Partner ID.

Below topic is configured in /N/IWXBE/OUTBOUND_CFG

Create BP

Check /IWXBE/EVENT_MONITOR

You see only Business partner ID in the payload.

However, business requirements often demand additional contextual data like first name and last name to be included in the event payload. This blog post demonstrates how to enrich SAP business partner events with custom fields using derived events.

The Challenge

By default, when a Business Partner is created or modified in SAP S/4HANA, the outbound event payload typically contains only the Business Partner number. While this is sufficient for basic integrations, many real-world scenarios require additional information to avoid unnecessary callback requests to the source system.

Solution Overview

We can leverage SAP's event binding mechanism and receiver function modules to create derived events that include custom fields in the payload. This approach allows us to:

  • Enhance event payloads with additional business data
  • Reduce the need for subsequent API calls
  • Improve integration performance and efficiency
  • Maintain clean separation between standard and custom logic

Implementation Steps

Step 1: Create Abstract entity

define abstract entity Z_ABSTRACT_ENTITY_BP
{
  businesspartner : abap.char(10);
}

Step 2: Create root view entity with the field which you want to add in the payload.

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Add fields to standard Business Event Payload'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define root view entity Z_CUSTOM_PAYLOAD_BP
  as select from but000
{
  key name_first,
  key name_last
}

Step 3: Create behavior definition and behavior implementation class as shown below.

managed implementation in class zbp_custom_payload_bp unique;
strict ( 2 );

define behavior for Z_CUSTOM_PAYLOAD_BP //alias <alias_name>
persistent table but000
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
{
  event bpchanged parameter Z_ABSTRACT_ENTITY_BP;
  event bpcreated parameter Z_ABSTRACT_ENTITY_BP;
}
CLASS zbp_custom_payload_bp DEFINITION PUBLIC ABSTRACT FINAL FOR BEHAVIOR OF z_custom_payload_bp.
  TYPES: tt_events_change        TYPE TABLE FOR EVENT z_custom_payload_bp~bpchanged,
         tt_events_create TYPE TABLE FOR EVENT z_custom_payload_bp~bpcreated.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS:raise_bp_changed
      IMPORTING it_events TYPE tt_events_change,
      raise_bp_created IMPORTING it_events TYPE tt_events_create.
ENDCLASS.

CLASS zbp_custom_payload_bp IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD raise_bp_changed.
    lcl_event_handler=>on_bp_changed( it_events ).
  ENDMETHOD.
  METHOD raise_bp_created.
    lcl_event_handler=>on_bp_created( it_events ).
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

In local types of Behavior implementation class,

CLASS lcl_event_handler DEFINITION FRIENDS zbp_addr_changed.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS: on_bp_changed IMPORTING it_events TYPE zbp_custom_payload_bp=>tt_events_change,
      on_bp_created IMPORTING it_events TYPE zbp_custom_payload_bp=>tt_events_create.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_event_handler IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD on_bp_changed.
    RAISE ENTITY EVENT z_custom_payload_bp~bpchanged FROM it_events.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD on_bp_created.
    RAISE ENTITY EVENT z_custom_payload_bp~bpcreated FROM it_events.

  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

Step 4: Create Custom Event Definition

Step 5: Configure custom event in the outbound bindings

Step 6: Create receiver function module

This will intercept the standard Business Partner event and raise the derived event with enhanced payload:

FUNCTION ztest_bp_receiver_fm.
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*"  IMPORTING
*"     VALUE(EVENT) LIKE  SWETYPECOU-EVENT
*"     VALUE(RECTYPE) LIKE  SWETYPECOU-RECTYPE
*"     VALUE(OBJTYPE) LIKE  SWETYPECOU-OBJTYPE
*"     VALUE(OBJKEY) LIKE  SWEINSTCOU-OBJKEY
*"  EXPORTING
*"     VALUE(REC_ID) LIKE  SWELOG-RECID
*"  TABLES
*"      EVENT_CONTAINER STRUCTURE  SWCONT
*"  EXCEPTIONS
*"      READ_FAILED
*"      CREATE_FAILED
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
  SELECT SINGLE name_first,name_last FROM but000 WHERE partner = @objkey INTO (ls_bp).
  IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
    zbp_custom_payload_bp=>raise_bp_changed( it_events = VALUE #( (
                                                         name_first = ls_bp-name_first
                                                         name_last = ls_bp-name_last
                                                         %param = VALUE #( businesspartner = objkey )
                                                         ) ) ).

  ENDIF.

ENDFUNCTION.

Step 7: Register Event Linkage

Link the standard Business Partner event to your receiver function module using transaction SWE2:

  1. Execute transaction SWE2
  2. Create a new entry with:
    • Object Type: Business Partner object type (e.g., BUS1006)
    • Event: The standard event (e.g., CHANGED)
    • Receiver Type: Function Module
    • Receiver Function Module: ZTEST_BP_RECEIVER_FM
  3. Save the configuration

Step 8: Test the Implementation

Now it's time to verify that everything works as expected:

  1. Modify an existing Business Partner (change any field)

 

2. Navigate to /N/IWXBE/EVENT_MONITOR

  1. Locate your derived event in the event list
  2. Examine the payload

 

You should now see an enriched payload containing:

json

 {

 "name_first": "Derived events",

 "name_last": "Demo",

 "businesspartner": "0001000260"

}

Important Note for BP Creation Events:

If you want to trigger the derived event at the time of Business Partner creation, you need to add an additional entry in SWE2 for the CREATED event. You have two options:

Option 1: Same Payload for Both Events If the payload structure is identical for both creation and modification events, you can use the same receiver function module for both events:

  • Create an entry in SWE2 for event CREATED pointing to ZTEST_BP_RECEIVER_FM
  • Create an entry in SWE2 for event CHANGED pointing to ZTEST_BP_RECEIVER_FM

Option 2: Different PayloadsIf you require different payload structures for creation and modification events, perform the following:

  • Create a separate receiver function module (e.g., ZTEST_BP_RECEIVER_CREATE_FM) for the creation event
  • Implement the custom logic for the creation payload
  • Add a separate entry in SWE2 for event CREATED pointing to the new function module
  • Keep the existing entry for CHANGED event pointing to ZTEST_BP_RECEIVER_FM

Best Practices

  • Always handle database read errors gracefully
  • Consider performance implications when querying large datasets
  • Document your custom events clearly for API consumers
  • Use meaningful naming conventions for custom events and function modules
  • Test thoroughly in development before deploying to production
  • Monitor event processing to ensure reliability

Conclusion

Derived events provide a powerful mechanism to enhance standard SAP events with custom business data. By following the steps outlined in this blog post, you can significantly improve the value of your event-driven integrations without modifying standard SAP objects.

This approach maintains clean separation between standard and custom code while providing the flexibility needed for real-world integration scenarios. Whether you're building microservices, integrating with external systems, or creating event-driven architectures, enriched event payloads will help you build more efficient and maintainable solutions.

Additional Resources

  • Steps to publish business events 

Have you implemented derived events in your SAP landscape? Share your experiences and questions in the comments below!

Event-driven architecture SAP Event Mesh

entry.title: Re: Guidelines for content created with generative AI
entry.content:
@KjetilKilhavn I do appreciate your response and take your points. However:

  1. SAP employees are already clearly identified with a little SAP logo badge. Thus, I don't think "SAP Champion" creates any confusion. Here SAP means more of a expertise area not affiliation or employer.
  2. Community leaders are very often topic experts too. One needs to have some expertise to share knowledge and knowledge sharing is what the SAP community is mostly about.
  3. We are here in SAP community, not a local archery or a school band. Therefore it does make sense to keep SAP in the badge title. Once the badge is displayed on e.g. LinkedIn clear information on what kind of community one excels in is valuable.

Still, these is just my point of view. We are different people, perfectly entitled to various positions. It is good to have them and be able to freely discuss them.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: How to include the stock available in cross plant during the MRP run
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are currently facing an issue with our MRP run. The system is not considering available stock in other plants during the MRP execution. As a result, it shows a shortfall and unnecessarily raises purchase requisitions, even though the required material is actually available in one of our other plants.

To address this, we would like to explore the feasibility of running MRP across multiple plants based on user selection. This would help in optimizing stock utilization across locations and avoiding redundant procurement.

Could you please suggest how to enable this functionality or suggest an alternative approach to achieve this?

Thanks in advance. 

Best Regards,

Dinesh

entry.title: Calling an external web service via https using the system certificate store
entry.content:
Hi,

SAP SQL Anywhere 17.0.10.5866 for WIndows

There is an external web service
Url: https://MyService.com/token
Request method: POST
Content-Type: x-www-form-urlencoded

Created a web procedure to call it:

CREATE PROCEDURE "dba"."TestAccessToken2"( in "client_id" long varchar,in "client_secret" long varchar,in "grant_type" long varchar ) 
result( "cAttribute" long varchar,"cValue" long varchar,"npp" integer ) 
url 'https://MyService.com/token'
set 'HTTP(VERSION=1.1)'
type 'HTTP:POST'
CERTIFICATE 'file=*'

Please note that in the body of this procedure, I specified ‚ÄúCERTIFICATE ‚Äòfile=*‚Äô‚Äù, which means that I want SQL Anywhere to use a certificate from the operating system's certificate store when calling an external web service via https.

 Example of calling this web procedure:

select * from dba.TestAccessToken2('Myclient' ,'MySecret', 'credentials')

When executing this code (calling the web procedure), I get an error message:

The secure connection to the remote host failed: The TLS handshake
failed, error code 0x20001040

Question: Am I calling this external web service correctly ?
Why is the error occurring‚Äîdid I specify something incorrectly, or is the required certificate missing from the system store ?

entry.title: Re: Âú®SAPÁ≥ªÁªüÊâÄÊúâË¥¶Â•óÂÖ±Áî®Ë∞ÉÊï¥Ê±áÁéá‰∏îÂèØ‰∏∫ËÆ∞Ë¥¶Ê±áÁéáÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÁª¥Êä§‰∫ÜÊ±áÁéáÂêéÔºåÈÇ£ÂêéÁª≠ÊâÄÊúâË¥¶Â•óÊñ∞Â¢ûÁöÑË¥¶Âä°Â§ÑÁêÜÈÉΩ‰ºöÁî®Ëøô‰∏™Ë∞É...
entry.content:
Hello @lemon-xue ,

It is not quite clear whether the "Foreign exchange adjustment" refer to foreign currency valuation in the month-end closing, if yes, please find the following SSCUI can do the related setting:

entry.title: Uploading Email Templates into Emarsys using API
entry.content:
Uploading Email Templates Using API

We are in a Situation to migrate the data from other applications to SAP Emarsys . As the data is important for us we need to get everything that keeps the system up and running. Unfortunately, SAP doesn't offer any out of the box solution to migrate the templates(like we do with contact and product data).

Here is the Solution that we have found.

We are uploading the email templates using Code and "campaign.create" api offered by Emarsys.

We need:
  • Two APIs (one for getting the admin Id and another for uploading the Templates).
  • Python or NodeJS environment. (To trigger the email templates and for some preprocessing if required).
  • Emarsys Account Owner role.

 

Configuration

Go to Management > Security Settings in your Emarsys Account.

  • Go to API Tab 
  • Create an API(For getting Admin Details).
  • Note down the client secret in a secure location(You can see the secret while creating the API).
  • Next add permission for "admin.list" and "admin.get". (this may take time to update the permissions).
  • Please configure the postman with your clientID and secret.
  • Get your Admin Details (AdminID). Please refer https://dev.emarsys.com/docs/core-api-reference/qzdmscigu4ezh-list-administrator-accounts if you need some help.
  • Create another API(For uploading the templates).
  • Note down the API details.
  • Add permissions for "campaign.create" and "campaign.get".
Data Preparation

Considering the data is exported from the source system as Filename with CampaignName and data inside it is the actual template.
Otherwise its your preference to prepare the data.

Final Step
import os
import requests

# Replace with your actual credentials
CLIENT_ID = 'your_client_id'
CLIENT_SECRET = 'your_client_secret'
TOKEN_URL = 'https://auth.emarsys.net/oauth2/token'
UPLOAD_URL = 'https://api.emarsys.net/api/v3/email/templates'

# Step 1: Get access token
def get_access_token():
    payload = {
        'grant_type': 'client_credentials',
        'client_id': CLIENT_ID,
        'client_secret': CLIENT_SECRET
    }
    response = requests.post(TOKEN_URL, data=payload)
    response.raise_for_status()
    return response.json()['access_token']

# Step 2: Upload HTML templates
def upload_templates(folder_path, access_token):
    headers = {
        'Authorization': f'Bearer {access_token}',
        'Content-Type': 'application/json'
    }

    for filename in os.listdir(folder_path):
        if filename.endswith('.html'):
            campaign_name = os.path.splitext(filename)[0]
            with open(os.path.join(folder_path, filename), 'r', encoding='utf-8') as file:
                html_content = file.read()

            payload = {
                "name": campaign_name,
                "subject": f"{campaign_name} Subject",
                "from_email": "your-email@example.com",
                "from_name": "Your Name",
                "html": html_content
            }

            response = requests.post(UPLOAD_URL, headers=headers, json=payload)
            if response.status_code == 201:
                print(f"Uploaded: {campaign_name}")
            else:
                print(f"Failed to upload {campaign_name}: {response.text}")

# Run the script
if __name__ == "__main__":
    folder_path = 'path/to/your/templates'
    token = get_access_token()
    upload_templates(folder_path, token)
``

That's it.
If you have any doubt you can reach out to me @HariVeerendra

entry.title: Next Generation Just-In-Time, Supply to Customer - Example in System
entry.content:
In previous blog (Next Generation Just-In-Time, Supply to Customer -... - SAP Community), we made a brief introduction to Next Generation JIT S2C solution. In this blog, I would like to show how system run by testing in SAP internal S/4HANA Cloud Public edition system.

We still take the sequenced JIT call business in automobile industry as an example. After we confirm all the related master data are prepared, we test in system by reference the main process described in previous overview blog:

  1. Create the customer JIT Call manually by Fiori App Manage Customer JIT Calls

You specify the External JIT Call Number (This can be from customer), Customer Vehicle Number, Customer Vehicle Model and other customer information. These cover all the request information from customer.

Component Groups will be automatically determined after you added new components.

In App Monitor Customer JIT Calls, you may check all the created JIT Calls with the status showed.

  1. Following most actions related to JIT Calls can all be executed in App Manage Customer JIT Calls By Component Groups.

Select your Teams Name, appropriate functions that could be performed by this team are displayed. Click the action button to perform corresponding actions.

The first action is Create Packing Group:

After the action being successfully executed, you may check the application log by clicking the Application Log on the same screen.

The application log detail will tell you what happened to this JIT call by this action.

Now the Packing Group is created based on the package specification defined, and you will find the new created packing group in the component group information of JIT Call:

The Internal Processing Status was changed from JIT Call Created(0100) to Packing Group Allocated (0130):

Since we will supply the customer JIT request with production. Now we release the JIT call to production:

Updated status also displayed on the same screen:

Packing Group Status updated too:

After the production completed, we perform the confirmation by clicking Confirm Production:

Goods movement posted while performing the production confirmation with movement type 261 for component consumption and movement type 131 for product receiving.

  1. The we perform packing related actions here: Release to Packing, Confirm Packing, Create Handling Unit from Package Group, Create Outbound Delivery.

After the outbound delivery created, We can see the delivery number on the JIT call Component screen:

We perform picking via App Pick Outbound Delivery:

Outbound Deliveries for Goods Issue:

Material document with movement type 601 generated after goods issue posting:

  1. Then we create billing document via App Create Billing Documents.

Now we will see the status of all actions on the customer JIT Call are completed:

We have some reports for the insights of Just-In-Time Processing. You may use Demand Analysis for Customer JIT Calls to compare the Customer JIT Calls and schedule line from forecast delivery schedules.

Use Analyze stock availability for Customer JIT Calls to compare JIT Call request quantities and available stock quantities.

entry.title: Re: Designing UI5 Apps as Business Solution for SAP Build Work Zone - Part 2
entry.content:
Hi  @theodore_abitbol 

this is now completely confusing to me:

  • Are you really sure, that when you start the app, in the network trace you first find a request for "ui5AppInfo.json" failing with 404 and then a 2nd request https://dev-tal-ks9oev3t.launchpad.cfapps.eu20.hana.ondemand.com/701acd48-8d90-47d3-9921-993e6601220b.cap-ui.argonuiappappcockpitruptureracine/~6924a2b3-72d7-4bcf-aab7-93938be7cd4f~/manifest.json?sap-language=EN failing as well?
    This would be impossible, because the first request is needed to know the URL for the 2nd one. So the 2nd one can't be send in that case.
  • So if removing the destination for the app-host removes the HTML5 app completely, means that the app-host is not enabled for the golden path flow. This is a bit strange, because I can see some content on it, which only exists in that case. 
    Anyway, please ensure that in the MTA the content deployer which deploys the app, you have defined the XSUAA instance as required similar to how it is defined in my sample here: mta.yaml#L14 
  • If the app is not listed under HTML5 applications anymore but you can still call it via managed approuter is also strange. Being listed there is a requirement that the URL works.

I think it is not possible to solve the problem from this chat here and also floods this discussion thread.
Are you able to create a support incident for this? This would allow to provide more internal info and share credentials. Please create an incident on CA-UI5-FL-CLS. Provide

  • your project content (at least the MTA)
  • a network trace (har file, no screenshots)
  • Login credentials to reproduce
  • Maybe also access to your space for my user matthias.schmalz@sap.com

Best regards
Matthias

entry.title: Erfolgsfaktoren aus der ASCEND SAP S/4HANA Transformation bei Heidelberg Materials
entry.content:
Bei unserer monatlichen SAP Kaffee Ecke von SAP Training and Adoption erlebten wir diesmal einen besonders spannenden Praxisbericht zur SAP S/4HANA Transformation bei Heidelberg Materials. Christopher Gardner (Senior Change Consultant, Heidelberg Materials) und Hanna Mahnke (Change Management Consultant, SAP Digital Change & Adoption) gew√§hrten uns wertvolle Einblicke in das ASCEND Programm bei Heidelberg Materials ‚Äì mit besonderem Fokus auf den Menschen als zentralen Erfolgsfaktor im Change Management.

Eine kurze Umfrage zu Beginn verdeutlichte die Vielfalt unserer Teilnehmenden: 47% arbeiten im Change-Umfeld, 22% im Training-Bereich und 31% in anderen Bereichen wie Projektmanagement, Enterprise Architecture oder Vertrieb.

Praxisbericht aus dem ASCEND Programm - Ein Blick auf die SAP S/4HANA Migration

Heidelberg Materials ist mit rund 51.000 Mitarbeiterenden an √ºber 3.000 Standorten auf f√ºnf Kontinenten vertreten. Das Produktportfolio umfasst Zement, Zuschlagstoffe (Sand, Kies) und Beton.

Das ASCEND Programm f√ºhrt weltweit √ºber 30 L√§nder und globale Funktionen in Wellen auf SAP S/4HANA. Dabei sind mehr als 20.000 Nutzende betroffen. Eine besondere Herausforderung stellen die √ºber 500 angebundenen Anwendungen dar sowie die lokale Verantwortung mit hoher Individualisierung der SAP Systeme in den L√§ndern. Parallel laufen weitere IT Projekte und Initiativen. Die ersten L√§nder sind bereits 2025 live gegangen, weitere Wellen folgen bis 2028.

Organizational Change Management (OCM): Struktur und Philosophie

Erstmals wurde ein dediziertes OCM-Team in die Projektorganisation eingebettet. Das Team wird von Katharina Fischer als Change Lead gef√ºhrt. Hanna Mahnke und Christopher Gardner verantworten Kommunikation und Analytics, w√§hrend Nancy Otanez und Thomas Stangl das Training verantworten. Auf L√§nderebene fungieren Country Transformation Leads (CTLs) als zentrale Ansprechpartner:innen, die wiederum mit den lokalen Key Usern interagieren.

Das ASCEND Programm verfolgt das Leitprinzip, dass es sich hierbei nicht nur um eine digitale, sondern vor allem um eine menschenzentrierte Transformation handelt. Systeme und Prozesse funktionieren erst dann optimal, wenn Menschen bef√§higt, informiert und aktiv integriert werden.

Erfolgsfaktoren f√ºr SAP S/4HANA Transformationen im Change Management

 

 

 

Change Leadership und fr√ºhzeitige Stakeholder-Beteiligung

Das Change Team bei HM investierte bereits sehr fr√ºh im Projekt viel Zeit in die Einbindung der lokalen Stakeholder. Die strukturierte Einbindung erfolgte von Global Process Owner:innen √ºber Country Transformation Leads bis hin zu Key User:innen und Endanwender:innen ‚Äì also √ºber alle Hierarchieebenen hinweg. Ein gemeinsam erarbeiteter Workshop legte das Fundament f√ºr Change Vision, Mission und Werte als roter Faden durch alle Projektphasen. Der daraus resultierende interaktive Austausch bildete ein solides Fundament f√ºr die weitere, vertrauensvolle Zusammenarbeit.

Change Strategy & Plan / Change Leadership

Global-lokal verzahntes Vorgehen

Das Country Transformation Lead (CTL)-Netzwerk fungiert als wichtiges Bindeglied zwischen globaler Steuerung und lokaler Umsetzung. Zweimal monatlich finden CTL-Calls mit Status-Updates und Peer-Austausch statt. Globale Frameworks, die das Change Projektteam zur Verf√ºgung stellt, werden lokal angepasst, w√§hrend kontinuierliches Feedback das Change Framework sch√§rft.

Change-Kommunikation

Ein durchdachter Kommunikationsplan dient als Bibliothek mit Kommunikationsschritten und -templates f√ºr jede Projektphase und Zielgruppe. Durch lokale Anpassung von Timing und Tonalit√§t sowie √úbersetzungen werden die lokalen Kapazit√§ten, Arbeitslast und Kultur ber√ºcksichtigt. Auch hier spielen die Country Transformation Leads eine zentrale Rolle, da sie vor Ort entscheiden, wann welche Aktivit√§t umgesetzt wird und bilden damit eine wichtige Br√ºcke von der globalen zur lokalen Organisation.

Change Analytics - Datengetriebenes Change Management am Puls der Zeit

Regelm√§√üige Pulse Checks bei Projektteam, Key User:innen und Endanwender:innen erfassen aktuelle Zuversicht, Trainingsnutzung und Zuversicht. Die Ergebnisse bieten wertvollen Einblick, inwieweit die bisherigen Change Ma√ünahmen greifen oder angepasst werden m√ºssen. Dabei kann auch eine Wahrnehmung, wie es g√§be ‚Äûzu viele Meetings", hinterfragt und durch Zusatzfragen validiert werden.

Training

Die Rollen- und Aufgabenverteilung sieht didaktisch-methodische Leitplanken vor, w√§hrend die inhaltliche Ausarbeitung gemeinsam mit den Workstreams erfolgt. Das Projektteam erstellte √§hnlich wie beim Projektplan ein Angebot, das vor Ort ausgestaltet werden kann. So wurden etwaige Widerst√§nde vor Ort direkt gel√∂st oder entstanden erst gar nicht. Die Durchf√ºhrung der Trainings liegt in der Verantwortung der L√§nder. Hierzu wurden die Key User:innen in einem Train-the-Trainer-Ansatz als Multiplikator:innen bef√§higt. Das Change Team stellte √ºbergreifende Tools und Content in Englisch zur Verf√ºgung, die Lokalisierung erfolgt in den L√§ndern. Eingesetzte Tools sind SAP Enable Now (inkl. Companion), Inhalte sind in Workday verf√ºgbar.

Lernen, Verstehen, Anpassen

Die iterative Weiterentwicklung √ºber den mehrj√§hrigen Projektzeitraum umfasst Retrospektiven nach der ersten Welle mit konkreten Action Items. Dazu geh√∂rten die Neuausrichtung des CTL-Netzwerks weg von Reporting hin zu Kollaboration, st√§rkere Lokalisierung des Key-User-Engagements sowie ein ‚ÄûFactory Approach" f√ºr wiederverwendbare Workpackages.

Diskussion und Q&A - Einblicke aus dem Austausch

Die anschlie√üende Fragerunde brachte spannende Details zur praktischen Umsetzung in Kommunikation, Training, Standardisierung, Kultur und der Rolle datengetriebener Steuerung:

Kommunikationsstrategie in der praktischen Umsetzung - Wie funktioniert der Kommunikationsplan konkret?

Der Plan wird als Angebot verstanden und umfasst Stakeholderanalyse sowie die Unterscheidung zwischen strategischer und operativer Kommunikation. Pro Land werden Kernbotschaften als ‚ÄûCountry Case for Change" erarbeitet. Das Muster f√ºhrt von Awareness zu konkreten Informationen, Templates helfen bei Adaption und Timing. Global produzierte Videos lohnten sich aus Christopher's Erfahrung nicht ‚Äì L√§nder setzen lieber auf eigene, kontextnahe Formate wie Statements lokaler F√ºhrungskr√§fte. People Manager Templates enthalten zus√§tzlich, was F√ºhrungskr√§fte wissen und leisten m√ºssen; l√§nderspezifische Erg√§nzungen erh√∂hen Relevanz und N√§he.

Motivation lokaler Ver√§nderungsrollen - Wie lassen sich lokale Change-Akteur:innen motivieren?

Statt eines Change Champion-Modells wurden Country Transformation Leads (CTL) etabliert, die vom Land benannt werden (meistens IT-Verantwortliche). Landesspezifische Kick-offs mit CTLs und Vision/Mission-Arbeit f√∂rdern den Aufbau einer Beziehungsebene und damit Ownership. Das Netzwerk funktioniert vor allem √ºber eine konstruktive Beziehungsebene auf Augenh√∂he und begleitete Entwicklung f√ºr die kommenden Aufgaben. So k√∂nnen wir, beispielsweis bei einer ausbleibenden R√ºckmeldung einzelner CTLs pers√∂nlich den Kontakt suchen anstatt in der Hierarchie zu eskalieren.

Schulungsbedarfsanalyse und Umsetzung - Wie werden Schulungsbedarfe identifiziert und umgesetzt?

Die Bedarfsanalyse wurde in der Explore-Phase basierend auf den Fit-to-Standard-Workshops erstellt. Die n√∂tigen Schulungs-Inhalte und Trainingsbedarfe werden gemeinsam mit den Stream Leads identifiziert. Im Train-the-Trainer-Ansatz werden die lokalen Key User:innen bef√§higt, die Inhalte lokal zu vermitteln. SAP Enable Now dient dabei als Autorentool, w√§hrend die Entscheidung f√ºr Formate (digital, Blended, Pr√§senz) l√§nderspezifisch getroffen wird. Im Grundsetup des Projekts waren 2-3 Ressourcen eingeplant, die offshore Content erstellt haben.

Rollenverst√§ndnis und Abgrenzung - Wie werden die Rollen CTL und Key User:in abgegrenzt?

CTLs fungieren als landesseitige Projekt- und Change-Schnittstelle, w√§hrend Key User:innen neben Test- und Trainingsaufgaben das lokale Change-Engagement in die Organisation tragen.

Standardisierung vs. lokale Gewohnheiten - Wie wird mit dem Spannungsfeld zwischen Standardisierung und lokalen Gewohnheiten umgegangen?

Global Process Owner:innen arbeiten zusammen mit lokalen Pendants zur Analyse der Ausgangslage pro Land. Die Fit-to-Standard Workshops finden in den L√§ndern statt, inklusive Beteiligung aller relevanten Rollen. Das Ziel der Standardisierung wird als notwendig angesehen, ist lokal jedoch mitunter schmerzhaft. Beteiligung und gemeinsame Zielbilder erleichtern die Akzeptanz und erm√∂glichen langfristig einfachere, schnellere und konsistentere √Ñnderungen.

Pr√§senz vor Ort und Budgetfragen - Wie lassen sich Investitionen in Vor-Ort-Pr√§senz rechtfertigen?

Aufgrund von Unsicherheiten in den L√§ndern und fr√ºheren Projekterfahrungen wurde gezielt in Vor-Ort-Pr√§senz investiert ‚Äì fachlich und emotional unterst√ºtzend, insbesondere vor Go-Live. Die F√ºhrung unterst√ºtzte die Bedeutung; in Einzelf√§llen wurden Reisekosten zentral √ºbernommen f√ºr Tests und um damit Sicherheit zu schaffen.

Interkulturelle Unterschiede meistern - Wie werden interkulturelle Herausforderungen bew√§ltigt?

Das Headquarter wird erfahrungsgem√§√ü als Hierarchie wahrgenommen ‚Äì das multinationale Projektteam federte schon einiges ab, zudem half auch die lokale Entscheidungshoheit erheblich. Viele kulturelle Themen werden √ºber die regionalen Strukturen gel√∂st, weitere Herausforderungen √ºber die pers√∂nliche Beziehungsebene. Christopher betonte, dass bekannte Gesichter und lokale Stimmen wesentlich mehr Wirkung entfalten als zentrale Botschaften aus der Hauptverwaltung

Mensch im Mittelpunkt ‚Äì wie bekommt man die relevante Aufmerksamkeit f√ºr den People-First-Ansatz?

Der Ansatz ist bei Heidelberg Materials nicht neu, erf√§hrt aber seit einigen Jahren wachsende Aufmerksamkeit mit mehr Ressourcen. Aus Hanna's Erfahrung in anderen Projekten bleibt es jedoch grunds√§tzlich problematisch, dass Change Management noch zu oft zu sp√§t hinzugezogen wird, was Ad-hoc-Ma√ünahmen n√∂tig macht. Ein fr√ºher Start und echte Beteiligung (mehr als reine Information) sind erfolgskritisch. Die Menschen sollten als Konstante vom Start √ºber Go-Live bis Hypercare im Mittelpunkt stehen.

Datengetriebene Steuerung in der Praxis - Wie funktioniert datengetriebenes Change Management konkret?

Pulse Checks liefern konkrete Zahlen zu Information, Trainingsnutzung und Zuversicht und erm√∂glichen gezieltes Gegensteuern durch gezielte Ma√ünahmen basierend auf Fakten. Die Wirkung einzelner Ma√ünahmen wird nachverfolgt, Ergebnisse st√§rken Argumentationen gegen√ºber dem Management und verbessern die Entscheidungsfindung bei der Priorisierung von Ma√ünahmen.

Fazit: SAP S/4HANA Transformation erfolgreich gestalten

entry.title: Overview of Posting Rules in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Posting Rules can be used for processing bank statement items. A posting rule determines exactly how a bank statement item is posted. It determines which accounts are posted to on debit and credit sides, and also whether or not the respective debit or credit side is cleared. Amongst other things, a posting rule can consist of a posting area, a debit/credit account symbol, a posting type and an on-account posting key.

They tell the system which G/L accounts to debit and credit, depending on the transaction type.

For example:
When a customer payment is received ‚Üí Debit the Bank Account, Credit the Customer Account.
When bank charges are posted ‚Üí Debit Bank Charges Expense, Credit Bank Account.

hese rules ensure that every business transaction results in correct and consistent accounting entries without manual intervention.

Where Posting Rules Are Used

Posting rules are mainly used in:

  • Bank Account Management / Cash Management(Apps like Manage Bank Statement Rules, Manage Automatic Payments, Manage Posting Rules, etc.)
  • Payment Processing
    (e.g., in scope items like J58 ‚Äì Bank Account Management )
  • Incoming and Outgoing Bank Statement Processing
    (via Manage Bank Statement Monitor or Reprocess Bank Statement Items apps)

How Posting Rules Work

Each posting rule defines:

  • Posting Area (e.g., subledger, G/L)
  • Debit/Credit Indicators
  • G/L Accounts to be used
  • Posting Keys
  • Document Type

For example:
When you process an incoming bank statement, a posting rule determines:

  • Which account should be debited (e.g., Bank Clearing Account)
  • Which account should be credited (e.g., Customer Receivables)

To understand what exactly a particular posting rule does (which accounts are posted and cleared), have a look at the table under Overview of the Posting Rules.

Viewing or Modifying Posting Rules

In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, configuration is managed via SAP-delivered content.
Therefore Posting rules are usually predefined by SAP and cannot be modified.

Examples of relevant SSCUIs (depending on your scope items and country version):

  • 102386 ‚Äì Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements
  • 102387 ‚Äì Assign Accounts to Posting Rules

How to View or Configure Posting Rules in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Unlike the on-premise system, where you use transaction codes (like OT83, OT74, etc.),
in the Public Cloud version, posting rules are managed via configuration activities (SSCUI) in the Manage Your Solution or CBC (Central Business Configuration) tool.

Step-by-Step: Viewing Posting Rules

Step 1: Access Configuration

  1. Go to the SAP Fiori Launchpad.
  2. Open the app Manage Your Solution (or Configure Your Solution in new systems).
  3. Choose Configure Your Solution tile.

Step 2: Find the SSCUI for Posting Rules

  1. In the search bar, enter:
    "Bank Statement" or "Posting Rules"
  2. Look for the following configuration activities (SSCUI IDs may vary slightly by country):
    102386 ‚Äì Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements
    102387 ‚Äì Assign Accounts to Posting Rules
    102385 ‚Äì Define Posting Keys and Posting Types

Step 3: Open the Configuration Step

  1. Click Open Activity.
  2. In Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements (102386), you can view all pre-delivered posting rules.
  3. Each posting rule shows posting area, posting type, debit/credit indicator, and document type.
  4. These rules are SAP-delivered and cannot be changed directly in Public Cloud to maintain integrity.

Step 4: Assign G/L Accounts

  1. Open Assign Accounts to Posting Rules (102387).
  2. Here you can see which G/L accounts are assigned to each posting rule and account symbol.
  3. You may adapt account assignments if your scope item allows (depending on business role and configuration permission).

Step 5: Test the Posting Rule

  1. Go to the app Manage Bank Statement Monitor or Reprocess Bank Statement Items.
  2. Upload or simulate a bank statement.
  3. The system automatically applies the posting rule based on the external transaction code or mapping configuration.
  4. You can then check the accounting document to verify which accounts were posted (via Display Journal Entries).

Modifying Posting Rules (Limitations in Public Cloud)

In Public Cloud, you cannot create or freely modify posting rules as in On-Premise or Private Cloud due to SAP‚Äôs standardization policy.

You can:

  • View and extend posting rules using SSCUI.
  • Assign or change G/L accounts linked to existing posting rules.
  • Create additional bank statement rules (via Manage Bank Statement Rules app) that determine which posting rule applies under certain conditions.

You cannot:

  • Add new posting areas.
  • Define entirely new posting rules or posting types beyond what SAP delivers.

Relevant Scope Items (Pre-Delivered Configurations)

Scope Item Description
J58Bank Account Management
J77Automatic Payments
J78Cash Operations
BD9

Bank Statement Processing

These scope items collectively handle posting rule configuration and bank integration.

entry.title: Re: Internal activities & service activity elements.
entry.content:
Hi Harsh,

This behavior is actually quite common when working with internal activities and service activity elements in SAP Project Systems. By design, cost planning doesn‚Äôt automatically roll up from service activity elements to their parent internal activity. Each service element maintains its own cost data, and unless specific cost roll-up or cost distribution settings are in place, the internal activity won‚Äôt reflect those planned costs.

To achieve what you‚Äôre trying to do, you‚Äôll need to make sure that the cost planning integration and aggregation settings are correctly configured. Start by checking your activity type assignment and cost element planning profiles. The internal activity should be linked to the same controlling area and cost element categories as the service elements to allow aggregation.

If you‚Äôre using standard cost planning transactions like CJ40/CJ42, try performing the cost plan at the WBS level and then executing a cost roll-up (CJ88 or CJ9E). This forces the system to consolidate the service element costs under the internal activity, which then enables period-wise distribution.

In some cases, organizations also handle this by defining a custom settlement rule or allocation cycle to move planned costs from service activities to internal ones. It depends on whether your controlling setup allows for that flexibility.

I‚Äôve seen a few SAP professionals deal with similar cost flow issues during internal activity mapping. Having reliable study and reference material, like the structured resources available through Pass4future, can make understanding these configuration relationships much easier before applying them in your system.

Hope this gives you a clearer path forward.

entry.title: Re: Marketplace App UX Design Guidelines for SAP Users
entry.content:
If you‚Äôre designing a marketplace app intended for SAP users, the key is aligning your UX with SAP‚Äôs Fiori Design Guidelines and general enterprise usability principles. SAP users are accustomed to consistency, clarity, and efficiency, so your marketplace should feel familiar while still being intuitive.

Here are some guidelines:

  1. Follow SAP Fiori principles ‚Äì focus on role-based, responsive, simple, and coherent design. Use familiar UI elements (tiles, cards, lists) that match Fiori‚Äôs visual language.
  2. Integrate smoothly with SAP workflows ‚Äì minimize context switching by ensuring data flows between your marketplace and SAP systems (e.g., S/4HANA or Ariba) with minimal user input.
  3. Keep navigation clear ‚Äì users should easily find suppliers, products, and orders. Use a simple top-level navigation or search-centric layout.
  4. Prioritize accessibility and performance ‚Äì enterprise users often multitask; responsive layouts and quick load times matter.
  5. Personalization and analytics ‚Äì show relevant items, purchase history, and quick actions based on user roles or past behavior.

SAP‚Äôs official Fiori Design Guidelines (experience.sap.com/fiori-design) are the best reference for UI patterns, layout grids, and interaction standards.

entry.title: Re: Goods receipt processing delay in SAP
entry.content:
When MII sends a GR confirmation to SAP, IDocs like MBGMCR or MBGMCR03 is processed immediately. The material document is created successfully. However, the update to the production order (AFKO/AFPO) ‚Äî specifically the ‚ÄúDelivered Quantity‚Äù field ‚Äî may not occur instantly. This update is typically handled by background jobs or update tasks that post-delivery quantities to the production order. Function modules like CO_ZV_ORDER_POST or whichever you are using are triggered post-GR. Update modules queued via V1/V2 update processes, which may be delayed due to system load or scheduling.

Go to SM13 to check if any update tasks are queued or delayed for the user or process.

The attribute used for SAML authentication depends entirely on the user's configuration and the values passed from their Identity Provider (IdP).

If the user base contains mixed identifiers‚Äîsuch as multiple domain names or inconsistent email formats‚Äîit is recommended to configure either a Custom SAML Mapping or use the User ID as the identifier. As long as the mapped values between SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and the IdP are consistent, authentication should function without any issues.

Regarding Joule/AI, there is no definitive SAP documentation explicitly stating that the NameID must be an email address. For reference, the official Joule integration guide can be found here:
Integrating Joule with SAP Analytics Cloud

entry.title: Re: Error message when using Import Sales Orders
entry.content:
Even if your data appears correct and the format is set to [TEXT], the ‚ÄúInvalid Format‚Äù error during import (as described in SAP Note 2977875) can still occur due to hidden formatting issues, invisible characters, or mismatches between expected and actual field structures.

Even when everything looks fine, SAP‚Äôs import validation is strict. Here are the most frequent culprits:

Excel or CSV files may contain non-printable characters, extra spaces, or UTF-8 BOM markers. These can cause SAP to reject fields even if they appear correct. The solution is to open the file in a plain text editor (like Notepad++) and enable ‚ÄúShow All Characters‚Äù to inspect hidden symbols.

SAP expects specific field lengths and data types like numeric, date or text. If a field exceeds the allowed length or contains unexpected characters (e.g., letters in a numeric field), it triggers the error. The solution is to cross-check your file against the template or metadata provided by SAP for that import scenario.

Even if duplicates are not obvious, SAP may detect them based on internal keys (e.g., material number + plant). The solution is to sort and de-duplicate your file based on key fields.

Some systems interpret .csv or .txt differently depending on separators (comma vs tab). The solution is to try saving the file explicitly as UTF-8 encoded CSV with correct delimiters.

So in order to overcome from all the above "Invalid format" error is, validate with SAP‚Äôs Import Template and download the official template for your import scenario and paste your data into it. Use SAP Fiori App ‚ÄúImport Monitor‚Äù. It may show more granular error messages. Test with Minimal Data and try uploading just one or two rows to isolate the issue.

Check SAP Help Portal on Import Sales Quotations explains how invalid entries are flagged.

entry.title: Managing Change When Adopting AI
entry.content:
Adopting AI

The benefits of AI in supply chain management are evident, but implementing it might not be as clear.
Change management is an important aspect of any implementation which needs to be taken into consideration and made a priority ahead of any roll-out. Change management needs to be a high priority to ensure adoption. 
 
Conversational Planning

 In this blog, I'll explore the following topics

  • Change Management
  • How to practically adopt AI in SCM?

Change Management

Change management always starts with clear communication about the value of the upcoming change and crafting a plan that involves user input. AI in the supply chain will improve human experiences by automating repetitive tasks, enabling employees to learn new skills that will benefit both the business and their personal growth. With the conversational planning use case in SAP S/4HANA Transportation Management, a user can now reduce their planning time by at least 50% with the help of AI. This use case compliments the user's domain knowledge with AI driven data and real-time information. e.g. Plan all products that need to be transported to Orlando on a semi-truck with a 53' trailer. A user will interact through natural language. 

How to practically adopt AI in SCM?

Once a use case is setup in the test environment, users need to be trained on the new process to ensure better success. This is a link to the initial setup. SAP note 3573759 has more information of setting up conversational planning in SAP TM. The testing phase needs to be thorough with real-life data. These kinds of changes will probably require a pilot phase and can be rolled out once the value has been proven, these employees are likely to become your AI ambassadors fuelling excitement into the new technology which is always the best motivation for change ! Once the business is excited for these new improvements, these processes can be embedded in to the business. 
 
Route Planning with AI
 

This blog was an overview of what can be expected when implementing AI use cases in supply chain management and how to deal with change management.

In my next blog I plan to cover the another AI use case in SAP Transportation Management, AI assisted good receipt analysis. 

For more updates on Transportation Management please visit  https://community.sap.com/topics/transportation-management

A link to the configuration guide  https://me.sap.com/notes/3573759

If you have any questions on Transportation Management please visit https://answers.sap.com/tags/01200615320800000686

Feel free to connect with me on LinkedIn http://www.linkedin.com/in/ravine-lala-logistics .

entry.title: Re: Firm Zone and Trade Off Zone dates in Schedule line-S...
entry.content:
Hi,

The Firm Zone and Trade-Off Zone dates are not directly stored as date fields in the system.
They are derived values, calculated based on the number of days defined in the scheduling agreement item.
Currently, the Firm Zone/Trade-Off Zone indicators used for determining these dates are not exposed in any released CDS view for direct reporting or printing.
Hence, the standard Scheduling Agreement output form does not include these fields by default.

Firm Zone / Trade-Off Zone Calculation

  • The Firm Zone and Trade-Off Zone are calculated using the number of days maintained in the scheduling agreement item:

    • End Date of Firm Zone = Current Date + Number of Days in Firm Zone

    • End Date of Trade-Off Zone = Firm Zone End Date + Number of Days in Trade-Off Zone

The released CDS view for purchasing scheduling agreement schedule lines - see KBA 3561564.

  • This view currently does not include the Firm Zone or Trade-Off Zone indicator fields.

  • To determine these zones, custom logic must be implemented using the item-level configuration data.

Adding Fields to Output Form

  • To include Firm Zone/Trade-Off Zone dates or subcontracting component details in the output form, use extensibility options as per KBA 3008187.

  • You can extend the data source or form template to include custom-calculated fields or additional details (e.g., component materials for subcontracting scheduling agreements).

Best regards,

SAP Support

  • Multi‚ÄëCloud Flexibility: Run workloads on AWS, Azure, or GCP.
  • Modern DevOps Experience: Container‚Äëbased runtime, CI/CD support, and open‚Äësource tooling.
  • New Services: Access to SAP‚ÄØBuild‚ÄØWork‚ÄØZone, SAP‚ÄØBuild‚ÄØProcess‚ÄØAutomation, SAP‚ÄØIntegration‚ÄØSuite, and SAP‚ÄØBusiness‚ÄØApplication‚ÄØStudio.
  • Future Compatibility: Long‚Äëterm SAP support and feature expansion.

2. Migration Roadmap Overview

Migration can be viewed in five phases:

Phase

Identify all active Neo services, subaccounts, and connected systems.

Plan

Migrate

8. Best‚ÄØPractices‚ÄØand‚ÄØTips

  • Use‚ÄØside‚Äëby‚Äëside‚ÄØmigration‚ÄØto‚ÄØminimize‚ÄØdowntime.
  • Regularly‚ÄØreview‚ÄØSAP‚ÄØNotes‚ÄØ.
  • Begin‚ÄØwith‚ÄØnon‚Äëproduction‚ÄØtenants.

  • Maintain‚ÄØa‚ÄØrollback‚ÄØplan‚ÄØand‚ÄØtrack‚ÄØmanual‚ÄØsteps.

9. Conclusion

Migrating‚ÄØfrom‚ÄØNeo‚ÄØto‚ÄØCloud‚ÄØFoundry‚ÄØis‚ÄØa‚ÄØstrategic‚ÄØimperative‚ÄØto‚ÄØleverage‚ÄØSAP‚Äôs‚ÄØnext‚Äëgeneration‚ÄØcloud‚ÄØcapabilities.
By‚ÄØfollowing‚ÄØthis‚ÄØroadmap‚ÄØand‚ÄØleveraging‚ÄØSAP‚Äôs‚ÄØMigration‚ÄØPacks‚ÄØand‚ÄØofficial‚ÄØguides,‚ÄØyou‚ÄØcan‚ÄØachieve‚ÄØa‚ÄØsmooth,‚ÄØsecure,‚ÄØand‚ÄØfuture‚Äëproof‚ÄØtransition.

entry.title: How to access 'Posting parameters' tab in 'Manage Contract' app contract screen
entry.content:
Dear Community,

We are currently facing an issue where the Posting Parameters tab is not appearing in the RECN Contract screen.

Could you kindly assist us in identifying:

  • Why the Posting Parameters tab is not visible in our RECN screen?
  • What specific configuration settings or screen layout variants need to be activated to enable this tab?
  • Whether any field group assignments or view variants  are required for this functionality?

We would appreciate your guidance on the necessary steps to resolve this and ensure the tab is available for contract postings.

Thanks & regards.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to access 'Posting parameters' tab in 'Manage Con...
entry.content:
Hi and thank you for the question!

There are multiple ways to achieve what you are looking for.

The screen sequence can be adjusted for the specific contract type in SSCUI 103849 - Define Contract Types. In this configuration activity, there are several pre-delivered screen sequences which you can review to see which one aligns with your requirements the closest. This screen sequence setting adjusts only the 'Manage Contract' app by contract type maintained.

In addition, posting parameters themselves are accessible directly via the contract condition. You can navigate to the contract condition in question, and select the 'Term' section for the condition. Here, posting terms, frequency terms and more can be maintained directly.

I would also recommend reviewing best practices and test scripts available for the specific scope items via the SAP Help Portal. The documentation explains in detail the functionalities and how to access them, both for the older 'Manage Contract' GUI app, and the new 'Contract Management' Fiori app, which I also recommend checking out as new developments will be focusing on the Fiori Apps.

In the 'Contract Management' App, you can also access the 'Posting Parameters' section and edit the entries directly.

entry.title: NOW AVAILABLE!! SAP Ariba Sourcing and Procurement for Public Sector for S/4HANA
entry.content:
Highlight:

  • The solution provides state of the art solution tailored to cater public sector specific needs from Procure-to-Pay and Source-to-Pay business scenarios.
  • It allows customers to switch individual public sector features catering to their business needs.
  • The solution is integration points with external parties for Contract Authoring as well as Record Management.
  • It has multiple extension points available for customers to make it retrofit into custom developments.

 

Features:

The solution features rich set stretched from Pre-awarding, awarding and Post awarding process in the cycle of Sourcing and Procurement.

The solution is built with close collaboration with major public sectors from US and France to ensure the delivered features will resolve their key challenges and overcome the setback from erstwhile solution. Some notable public sector features are:

  • Smart Numbers
  • De-obligation
  • Pricing Arrangements
  • Incremental Funding with Fund Requests
  • Mixed Contracts
  • Multiple Suppliers
  • Novation

Technical Layout:

The complete solution is compile with suite of fiori applications which can work standalone but best suited when worked in symphony.

The solution leverage latest Restful ABAP Programming framework and Fiori Element 4.0 as technology stack.

The solution delivers multiple business switches as well customizing level switches to ensure customer can activate features which is more relevant.

Behind the scene the solution enriched with full power house of standard procurement and sourcing processes.

Some key applications which is in addition to standard procurement and sourcing application:

  • Manage Fund Request
  • Process Novation
  • Process Deobligation
  • Manage Entity Hierarchies

The product is general availability is active from October 8th, 2025.

More features are in the roadmap for the upcoming feature pack 01.
